importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The subprime car delinquency rate doubled from 2021 to 2025, with the first recorded high in January 2025.
The default rate among subprime borrowers reached 11% in September 2025, the highest level since the Great Recession.
Motor vehicle repair costs surged 15% year-over-year in August 2025, the largest increase in nearly two years.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2021 to 2025 shows a doubling of subprime car loan delinquency from 2021 to 2025, reaching 6.43% — worse than during past recessions.
A surge in car loan defaults and repossessions occurred over the past two years, with the trend continuing into 2025.
The financial stress on subprime borrowers stabilized in 2025 after significant increases in late payments and repossessions.

keyTakeAways: The delinquency rate among subprime borrowers (credit scores below 670) has doubled since 2021 to 6.43%, the highest level since early 1990s, with the only higher point being January 2025.
Car loans are among the last payments Americans are willing to miss, as cars are essential for work, family, and food access.
Record car prices, high interest rates, and inflation have driven average auto payments to record levels, increasing financial strain on borrowers.
Motor vehicle repair costs surged 15% year-over-year in August 2025, the largest increase in nearly two years, and car insurance prices rose 5% in one month.
Two years after pandemic-related pauses, student loan payments resumed and began affecting credit scores, worsening financial stress.
The gap between prime (credit scores ≥670) and subprime delinquency rates (under 0.5% vs. 6.43%) highlights the K-shaped economy, where affluent consumers thrive while lower-income ones struggle.
Lenders are investing in GPS tracking and ignition disabling technologies to facilitate repossession, signaling activity levels comparable to the Great Recession.
Subprime delinquency and repossession rates are at their highest since 2008, signaling a serious economic warning sign for vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: Fitch Ratings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fitch Ratings provided the data showing that the subprime car delinquency rate has doubled since 2021 to 6.43%.

namedEntities.name: Cox Automotive
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A leading automotive data and analytics company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cox Automotive reported that the default rate among subprime borrowers reached 11% in September 2025, indicating severe financial distress.

namedEntities.name: Experian
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Experian data showed that 46% of used car loans have payments of $500 or more, and 8% of new car loans have payments over $1,000.

namedEntities.name: Bureau of Labor Statistics
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. government agency that collects and analyzes economic data
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a 15% year-over-year surge in vehicle repair costs in August 2025.

namedEntities.name: Jonathan Smoke
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jonathan Smoke emphasized that 'there’s no room for error' in the financial stability of subprime borrowers.

namedEntities.name: Rod Chadehumbe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief asset-backed securities strategist at Bloomberg Intelligence
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rod Chadehumbe noted that prime borrowers are not struggling, highlighting the disparity between wealthy and financially vulnerable Americans.

namedEntities.name: Pamela Foohey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Law professor at the University of Georgia, expert in auto finance and bankruptcies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pamela Foohey explained how lenders now use GPS and ignition disabling to track and repossess cars, signaling a surge in repossession activity.

namedEntities.name: George Badeen
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of Midwest Recovery and Adjustment in Detroit and a trade group leader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: George Badeen noted that repo numbers suggest activity levels comparable to the Great Recession, indicating a highly active repossession market.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A significant rise in car loan delinquency among subprime borrowers — those with credit scores below 670 — has emerged in the United States, with the delinquency rate doubling since 2021 to reach 6.43%, the second-highest level since the early 1990s. This marks a worsening trend compared to past recessions, including the Great Recession and the pandemic. The surge is driven by record car prices, high interest rates, rising repair and insurance costs, and the resumption of student loan payments after pandemic pauses. Lenders are now actively using GPS tracking and ignition disabling to repossess vehicles, signaling a level of economic distress similar to the Great Recession. The stark contrast between subprime and prime borrowers highlights the 'K-shaped economy,' where wealthier individuals thrive while lower-income consumers face financial collapse. This growing crisis reveals a deeper structural issue: widespread economic hardship beneath the surface of overall economic growth and stock market performance.
title: A significant group of Americans are falling behind on their car payments - an economic warning sign
